instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used in the related study on improving the identification of colorectal cancer (CRC) at early and advanced stages?
Output: In the related study, urine surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy was used to improve the identification of colorectal cancer (CRC) at early and advanced stages.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the related study to improve the identification of colorectal cancer (CRC) at early and advanced stages?
Output: Principal component analysis (PCA) and support vector machine (SVM) algorithm were used in the related study to improve the identification of colorectal cancer (CRC) at early and advanced stages.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the machine learning algorithm combined with urine surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy in improving the identification of colorectal cancer (CRC) at early and advanced stages, and how far can this metric go?
Output: The specific metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the machine learning algorithm combined with urine surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy was diagnostic accuracy. instruction: How did the diagnostic accuracy of linear discriminant analysis (LDA) compare to support vector machine (SVM) in improving the identification of colorectal cancer (CRC) at early and advanced stages using urine surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy and PCA-SVM as the machine learning algorithm?
Output: The diagnostic accuracy of linear discriminant analysis (LDA) was 80.95%, while the diagnostic accuracy of support vector machine (SVM) was 93.65%. instruction: Can urine surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy combined with PCA-SVM be considered a superior method for improving the identification of colorectal cancer (CRC) at early and advanced stages compared to traditional diagnostic methods?
Output: Yes, urine surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy combined with PCA-SVM can be considered a superior method for improving the identification of colorectal cancer (CRC) at early and advanced stages compared to traditional diagnostic methods.
